As part of the asset management life cycle, a company engages a certified equipment disposal vendor to appropriately recycle and destroy company assets that are no longer in use. As part of the company's vendor due diligence, which of the following would be MOST important to obtain from the vendor?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. A copy of the procedures used to demonstrate compliance with certification requirements.

comments.content: I think D is the MOST important (which is what the question is asking for) and B would also be nice to have.

discussion.content:
Its definitely not NDA because we are yet to hire the vendor. "due diligence" happens before you purchase a service. 

Its either B or D. I will mostly go over B as audit reports are what available for public consumption from service providers (ex: SOC Audit reports)

FWIW: here is an excerpt from the equipment disposal requirements of an actual corporation:
ISO 27001 Information Security Management System - Information Security Policy Document Number: OIL-IS-POL-IS-1.0 Version :1.0 
1.5.Confidentiality agreements
"Whenever communications with third parties necessitate the release of the Company’s sensitive information, a standard Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA) or confidentiality clause, authorised by the Company’s Legal department, will be signed by the third party." 
https://oilweb.oilindia.in/policy/Information_Security_Polciy_2013.pdf

D is the right answer. When you destroy media, you should obtain a certificate that attests that the media was sanitzed/destroyed and details the methods used. If somehow an attacker is still able to get data from that media, that certificate is used as evidence you exercised due diligence to support you were not negligent.

comments.content: do you make use of drugs?

What if you hired a vendor that was not certified to dispose of the media? For all you know, the vendor was secretly working for an enemy of the company, or the country. Then you were negligent. 
If the vendor did not sign an NDA, then the vendor is under no legal obligation to keep your information secret, and you may have no recourse against the vendor. Again, you were negligent because you did not receive such a signed contract.
The vendor claiming to have followed certain procedures is not a legal guarantee that your data was destroyed or protected.

discussion.content:
Maybe: B. A copy of the current audit reports and certifications held by the vendor?

Arguably: "A signed NDA that covers all the data contained on the corporate systems." An NDA is a binding legal contract. This may be the only thing that would give legal recourse if company information was exposed. Then again, the equipment should be disposed of in such a way that nothing is disclosed.

Arguably: "A copy of the procedures used to demonstrate compliance with certification requirements." But those should not be the concern of the company. If the vendor is certified, that should be assurance that the procedures used by the vendor are in compliance.

Best guess: "A copy of the current audit reports and certifications held by the vendor?" This could be a legal requirement. Certainly something you want to see.

choices.C: A signed NDA that covers all the data contained on the corporate systems.
choices.B: A copy of the current audit reports and certifications held by the vendor.
choices.D: A copy of the procedures used to demonstrate compliance with certification requirements.
choices.A: A copy of the vendor's information security policies.

questions.question_text:
A company's user community is being adversely affected by various types of emails whose authenticity cannot be trusted. The Chief Information Security Officer
(CISO) must address the problem.
Which of the following solutions would BEST support trustworthy communication solutions?

choices.D: Enabling SPF and DKIM on company servers.
choices.B: Using MFA when logging into email clients and the domain.
choices.C: Enforcing HTTPS everywhere so web traffic, including email, is secure.
choices.E: Enforcing data classification labels before an email is sent to an outside party.

discussion.content: D. Enabling SPF and DKIM on company servers.

comments.content:
A
DMARC binds SPF and DKIM together, so it's the more complete answer. DMARC plus a spam filter will eliminate almost all untrusted/unverified email.
https://www.smartertools.com/blog/2019/04/09-understanding-spf-dkim-dmarc

"DMARC, which stands for “Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance”, is an email authentication, policy, and reporting protocol. It builds on the widely deployed SPF and DKIM protocols, adding linkage to the author (“From:”) domain name, published policies for recipient handling of authentication failures, and reporting from receivers to senders, to improve and monitor protection of the domain from fraudulent email."

https://dmarc.org/
